cards.title: Transitions are grief in disguise
cards.remember: Your child is not fighting you. They are feeling a loss.
cards.say: I know you wanted more time. It is hard to stop.
cards.do: Hold the boundary and guide one tiny next step.
cards.ifEscalates: Use fewer words and stay physically close.

cards.title: Small protest, same need
cards.remember: Mild resistance still needs connection and clarity.
cards.say: You wanted one more minute. I hear you.
cards.do: Offer one small choice inside the transition.
cards.ifEscalates: Repeat one line and keep moving gently.

cards.title: Reset starts with your tone
cards.remember: A sharper moment does not erase safety.
cards.say: Let me try again. It is time to go, and I am with you.
cards.do: Lower your voice by one level and shorten the instruction.
cards.ifEscalates: Pause for one breath, then repeat one calm line.

cards.title: Connection first, then the limit
cards.remember: Giving in often means everyone was overloaded.
cards.say: This is hard. The plan is still to leave now.
cards.do: Name the feeling, then follow through with one clear action.
cards.ifEscalates: Drop extra language and prioritize calm movement.

cards.title: Limits can feel like rejection
cards.remember: The feeling is real even when the answer is no.
cards.say: You can be upset. The answer is still no.
cards.do: State the limit once, then stay present.
cards.ifEscalates: Do not negotiate. Keep one steady line.

cards.title: Warmth + boundary works
cards.remember: Calm consistency builds trust over time.
cards.say: I know you want it. Not today.
cards.do: Offer one acceptable alternative.
cards.ifEscalates: Return to the same line without adding more.

cards.title: Clarity beats perfect words
cards.remember: Not knowing what to do is part of hard parenting moments.
cards.say: I am here. The answer stays no.
cards.do: Plant your feet, soften your face, and wait out the wave.
cards.ifEscalates: Focus on safety and fewer words.

cards.title: Body needs look like behavior
cards.remember: A dysregulated body cannot cooperate on demand.
cards.say: Your body is tired or hungry. I will help.
cards.do: Lower expectations and meet the body need first.
cards.ifEscalates: Skip non-essential tasks until regulated.

cards.title: Catch it early
cards.remember: Early repair prevents bigger storms.
cards.say: Looks like your body needs a reset.
cards.do: Offer snack, water, or quiet rest before demands.
cards.ifEscalates: Move to a calmer environment immediately.

cards.title: Regulation before reasoning
cards.remember: When intensity is high, teaching can wait.
cards.say: Big feelings. We are doing body calm first.
cards.do: Reduce stimulation and co-regulate with slow breath and presence.
cards.ifEscalates: Prioritize rest and postpone non-urgent plans.

cards.title: Need for connection under the behavior
cards.remember: Some eruptions are bids for proximity, not defiance.
cards.say: You wanted me right now. I hear that.
cards.do: Offer brief connection, then restate the boundary.
cards.ifEscalates: Keep the connection cue short and predictable.

cards.title: Micro-connection can defuse
cards.remember: A short moment of attunement can lower intensity fast.
cards.say: I can give you one minute of full attention.
cards.do: Connect briefly, then transition to the next step.
cards.ifEscalates: Repeat the plan with one visual cue.

cards.title: Repair keeps trust intact
cards.remember: A quick repair restores connection after stress.
cards.say: I got loud. Let me try again. I am here.
cards.do: Return to a steady tone and set one clear expectation.
cards.ifEscalates: Drop to one sentence and stay grounded.

cards.title: Safety first, fairness later
cards.remember: In sibling conflict, containment comes before problem solving.
cards.say: I will not let anyone get hurt.
cards.do: Separate calmly, regulate, then return to repair.
cards.ifEscalates: Keep bodies apart and keep language minimal.

cards.title: Coach, do not court-room
cards.remember: Children learn repair faster than blame.
cards.say: Both of you are upset. We can solve this safely.
cards.do: Name each feeling in one line before problem solving.
cards.ifEscalates: Pause discussion and return to calming first.

cards.title: Containment before conversation
cards.remember: Escalated sibling moments need nervous-system reset first.
cards.say: I am resetting us. Safety first.
cards.do: Create physical space, lower volume, and stabilize both children.
cards.ifEscalates: End the discussion and do separate calm-down support.

cards.title: When the trigger is unclear
cards.remember: Unknown trigger does not mean no pattern.
cards.say: Something feels hard right now. I am here.
cards.do: Stabilize first, then log what you noticed.
cards.ifEscalates: Reduce stimulation and keep your line simple.

cards.title: Curiosity over control
cards.remember: Calm observation now builds insight later.
cards.say: I am with you. We will figure this out together.
cards.do: Track context after the moment without over-analyzing.
cards.ifEscalates: Shift to co-regulation and pause interpretation.

cards.title: Not sure is still data
cards.remember: Uncertainty is normal in the middle of stress.
cards.say: I do not need all the answers right now.
cards.do: Choose one stabilizing action and stay with it.
cards.ifEscalates: Keep safety and closeness as the only goals.

cards.title: Pause, then return
cards.remember: A brief reset can prevent bigger escalation.
cards.say: I am taking one breath and coming right back.
cards.do: Ensure safety, reset your nervous system, and reconnect quickly.
cards.ifEscalates: Call in support and reduce demands.

cards.title: Public transition, private safety
cards.remember: Public pressure can raise both your stress systems.
cards.say: We are stepping to a quieter spot together.
cards.do: Relocate, co-regulate, then continue with one-step guidance.
cards.ifEscalates: Exit the setting and preserve calm over completion.

cards.title: Boundary with reconnection
cards.remember: Stepping away briefly can help when done intentionally.
cards.say: I am right here when your body is ready.
cards.do: Hold the no, stay available, and rejoin with a calm cue.
cards.ifEscalates: Return to proximity without reopening negotiation.

cards.title: Two kids, one calm anchor
cards.remember: You do not need perfect fairness in the first minute.
cards.say: I am helping both of you calm first.
cards.do: Anchor one child with calm voice while setting distance for both.
cards.ifEscalates: Use short scripts and delay full debrief.

cards.title: Steadying yourself is care
cards.remember: Your regulation is an intervention, not a detour.
cards.say: I am calming my body so I can help yours.
cards.do: Slow exhale, relax shoulders, and keep one warm boundary.
cards.ifEscalates: Shrink the goal to safety and connection only.

lessons.title: Transitions without power struggle
lessons.body: You may notice transitions improve when you pair a warm acknowledgement with one concrete next step. Keep language short and predictable.

lessons.title: Holding limits with warmth
lessons.body: You may notice fewer escalations when the limit is stated once and your nervous system stays steady. Repetition and calm consistency do the work.

lessons.title: Body-state before behavior
lessons.body: You may notice intensity drops faster when hunger, fatigue, and overstimulation are treated first. Regulation creates room for cooperation.

lessons.title: Attention conflicts
lessons.body: You may notice that a brief, intentional connection moment can reduce protest more than repeated instruction.

lessons.title: Sibling conflict repair
lessons.body: You may notice sibling episodes shorten when safety and separation come first, and repair talk happens after regulation.

lessons.title: When patterns are still forming
lessons.body: You may notice trends emerge after a handful of quick logs. The goal is noticing, not perfect interpretation in the moment.

lessons.title: Parent reset as an intervention
lessons.body: You may notice outcomes improve when you repair quickly after a stress spike and return with one calm line.

lessons.title: Public meltdown containment
lessons.body: You may notice public moments de-escalate faster when you prioritize quiet relocation over explanation.
